text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with fancy crackers that's right
we're heading into peak entertaining
season and while i don't mind people
spending too much money on amazing
artisan cheeses it does bother me seeing
people paying seven or eight dollars for
a little package of fancy crackers at
those same shops which is why i'm so
excited to show you these easy to make
rosemary sea salt crackers which by the
way are technically crispy flatbreads
but we'll get into that a little later
for now let's get crack-a-lackin' and
begin by mixing up our dry ingredients
so in a mixing bowl we'll start with
some regular all-purpose flour to which
we will add some salt as well as a
little bit of sugar plus one single FLAC
of black pepper which is going to help
bring out the sweetness of that sugar
actually I'm just kidding
that was unintentional but have you said
that black pepper would work in this if
you wanted but anyway let's continue on
by stirring in some freshly grated
Parmesan cheese and the reason I like to
stir it into the flour at this point
before adding our liquid is so all those
little particles of cheese get coated
which I believe prevents it from
clumping together as we mix in the
liquid so that may or may not make a big
difference but it feels right but anyway
let's continue on by adding some freshly
chopped rosemary or of course another
fresh herb of your choice after all you
guys are the Russian hackers of these
homemade fancy crackers
allegedly so put what you want and once
our dough has been herbed we'll go ahead
and finish this off with a little bit of
extra virgin olive oil as well as last
but not least some nice cold fresh water
and then what we're going to do is grab
a fork and give this a mix until it
comes together to form a fairly soft
fairly sticky dough ball and this is
generally the same strategy whenever we
make a dough we want to start off on the
sticky side because it's always easier
to knead flour in then try to add more
liquid later and by the way do not worry
about over mixing this dough okay
there's two main varieties or crackers
there's the crispy flaky fragile sort of
biscuit style where it's critical not to
over mix the dough and then there's this
much sturdier crunchy ER flatbread style
which is what we're doing here where
that is not going to be an issue so like
I said we'll mix that together until our
dough ball forms at which point we'll
stop and transfer that onto a floured
surface where we're going to give it a
brief kneading adding as much flour as
necessary
till we have a dough ball that's still
relatively soft and supple but is no
longer too sticky to work with and
exactly how much flour that's going to
take is totally up to you
and your fingers because you're going to
feel it so I'll need it for a little bit
and if it feels like it's still too
sticky I'll work in a little more flour
until I think I'm going to be able to
roll it out nice and thin without any
major problems and again with a
traditional flaky biscuit style cracker
this would be a problem okay we don't
want to work the dough this much but for
the crispy flatbread style crackers
we're doing this is actually an
advantage so I continued on until mine
felt right at which point we are ready
to roll and cut our dough and you can if
you want to do this all at once but I'm
going to divide mine in half because I
think it's easier to work with plus I'm
just going to cook off one pan for the
sake of the video so I'm gonna go ahead
and cut that in half and then flour and
press down that piece so that like I
said we can roll this out relatively
thin and just like when we were kneading
the dough is you're doing this you're
going to dust it with enough flour to
keep it from sticking and what we're
shooting for here something that's at
least an eighth of an inch thick
or less alright if your dough is too
thick it'll still work and they'll still
Brown up in the oven and be crunchy but
they just won't have as nice a texture
so we're going to keep rolling until
it's at least this thin so like I said
about an eighth of an inch or less and
we can also check here that it's not
sticking to the table so now with
standing in any kind of uniform shape
that's looking pretty good and we can
move on to the next step which is
brushing this very lightly with water
and I do mean very lightly in fact you
can see some streaks here that look a
little lighter which is where I brush
down the water a little thick but it was
fine so maybe next time I'll spray it
but bottom line you want a moisten that
surface just a little bit because that's
what's going to make our topping stick
so once that said I'm going to go ahead
and sprinkle over some coarse sea salts
or if we were doing cedia crackers you
would do the exact same thing except
you'd sprinkle over poppy and sesame and
fennel seeds instead but this time I'm
just going with the salt and then once
that's been accomplished what we need to
do next is prick the dough or dock the
dough which is the official culinary
term and all that means is take a fork
as you see me doing here and pricking
that dough all over and no I don't go in
any particular pattern I prefer to do
this completely randomly and haphazardly
until the entire surface is pricked
sorry I mean docked
and above and beyond giving it a pretty
cool look when it's baked all those
little holes are going to prevent this
from puffing up too much in the oven
oh it'll puff up a little bit and we'll
have little blisters here and there but
not so much that it would affect our
desired texture and appearance and then
once our dough has been docked we'll
take a pizza cutter and cut these into
whatever shape and size we want and as
you're about to see I'm just going to go
with some nice boring plain rectangles
but obviously that's going to be up to
you triangles are nice as you've heard
me say before people like pointy food
but anyway I'm just going to go with
some right angles this time and if I
wasn't trying to make this look nice for
the pictures I probably would do any
trimming and I would just leave these
fairly irregular or as we call in the
business rustic but I did trim it up a
little bit and then what we'll do once
these are cut is transfer them onto a
lined baking sheet oh by the way make
sure you keep your fingers well floured
because we painted that surface with
water this stuff is really sticky and
hard to move as I just illustrate it
right there but one way or another we're
going to transfer these onto a baking
sheet which I've lined with a silicone
baking mat I'm guessing parchment paper
would also work nicely and once those
have been panned up we are ready to bake
so let's go ahead and transfer those
into the center of a 400-degree oven for
between like twelve and fifteen minutes
or until they're beautifully browned and
the exact time is going to depend on how
thick they are so these are what mine
look like after twelve minutes and as
you can see some look perfect but others
I think need a little more time so what
we'll do is pick off the ones that look
good yes painfully using our bare
fingers hey builds character but if you
have enough character and don't to burn
yourself you can use tongs but either
way we'll pull the ones that look good
off and simply pop the rest back in for
a few more minutes and while we're
waiting for those let's go ahead and
give this first batch the crunch test
you
oh yeah that sounds legit so just don't
be going by color make sure these are
crispy crunchy and cooked all the way
through and thanks to a few more minutes
in the oven that's eventually how all my
crackers ended up and that's it as soon
as all our crackers have cooled
completely they are ready to enjoy or if
we want I guess we could transfer them
into some kind of weathered basket and
take a few pictures and then enjoy them
and enjoy them I did and above and
beyond their gorgeous appearance and
crunchy texture I really do enjoy that
little hint of rosemary and parmesan in
these especially since these were made
specifically to go with some beautiful
beautiful Italian cheese so I went ahead
and served this up with some litter
which is actually made from goat sheep
and cows milk and really is every bit as
insanely delicious as it looks but no
matter what cheese are spreading on the
reason these flatbread style crackers
work so well is that they don't break
apart when you swipe on the cheese I
mean have you ever seen someone after
three glass of wine try to spray the
cheese like this on a thin regular
cracker it's not pretty
and there's crumbs everywhere and
there's cheese on their fingers but with
these that's not a problem they are as
user-friendly as they are tasty so in
conclusion is it really worth all that
extra time and effort to save a few
dollars making your own homemade fancy
crackers well of course not and now
we've got to pick a grape up off the
floor but despite all that I think you
should make these anyway because just
imagine living in a world where people
only did things that were worth the time
and effort personally I shudder at the
thought and I hope you feel the same so
I really do hope you give these a try
soon head over to food wishes comm for
all the ingredient amounts and more info
as usual and as always enjoy
you
